items.message: Sea spray overtopping is forecast along the coast as a result of high spring tides.  Forecast high water is 08:30 on 05/03/22 with a level of 6.30 mAOD and a Force 5 Northerly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Hinkley Point, mAOD is height above average sea level for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  Areas most at risk are the coastline between Gore Point and Hurlstone Point including Porlock Weir. Coastal conditions should ease for the 05/03/22 high tide at 20:45. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please be careful along beaches, promenades and coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated Saturday, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.78mAOD at 16:15 on 04/03/22 and 4.71mAOD at 04:30 on 05/03/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are peaking today. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 148 cubic metres per second and is falling slowly. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels continue to rise slowly at the Cae Howel river gauge following recent persistent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Llanymynech peaked at 2.83m overnight; Cae Howel 3.3 to 3.5m today, Friday 04/03/22. No further rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Saturday, 05/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Shardlow river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane, and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. 
Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from 18:00 today, 04/03/2022.  
Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to rise until late this evening, 04/03/2022.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/03/2022.

River levels have continued to fall throughout today 03/03/22 on the Upper River Wey and the river is now back within its banks. There may still be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall overnight and tomorrow. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding is not currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

River levels continue to rise slowly at the Lugwardine river gauge following recent persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday, 06/03/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message: River levels remain high and continue to rise slowly at the Tern - Walcot river gauge following recent persistent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington. We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. No further rainfall is forecast. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 05/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further rainfall is forecast.  
We continue to monitor the situation. 
Please avoid contact with flood water.

River levels have risen at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of persistent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected this afternoon, 04/03/2022 and into tomorrow 05/03/2022. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this evening, 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Thame following rainfall earlier in the week. Flooding of roads and farmland is expected to continue especially close to the river around Dorchester-on-Thames, Thame and Stadhampton. Light rain is expected overnight followed by scattered showers tomorrow (Saturday 5th March). River levels are now stable but we expect them to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, or as the situation changes.

River levels are continuing to fall at the Dernford river gauge, but levels remain high on the River Cam downstream. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Friday 04/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach. Further rainfall is forecast today, Friday 04/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high today, Friday 04/03/2022. River levels may rise again in response to further rainfall. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded, and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. We are closely monitoring the situation. This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected Friday evening, 04/03/22, and overnight into Saturday, 05/03/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. Predicted peaks:- Mythe 2.8m to 3.1m on Friday overnight into Saturday 05/03/22 Haw Bridge 4.0m to 4.3m 05/03/22 on Saturday morning, Sandhurst 3.6m to 3.8m 04/03/22 at 23:30, Gloucester 3.5m to 3.7m 04/03/22 at 22:45.   
Further rainfall is forecast at times over the next couple of days.  We expect river levels to remain high over the weekend.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  by 09:00 on 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have peaked and will remain steady, with no further rise forecasted.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.    
We continue to monitor the situation.

items.description: Severn estuary from Gloucester to Sharpness
items.message: High tides combined with high fluvial river levels will be at their highest between 22:30 Friday, 04/03/22 and 00:15 Saturday, 05/03/22 and 11:00 and 12:00 Saturday, 05/03/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is expected at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Severn Estuary from Sandhurst to Chepstow and Sharpness. Locations affected; low lying land at Lower Rea and Elmore Lane West may be flooded. High tides may also affect watercourses draining into the Severn Estuary. Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 3.6m to 3.8m 04/03/22 at 23:30 and 3.6m to 3.9m on 05/03/22 at 11:15, Gloucester 3.5m to 3.7m 04/03/22 at 22:45 and 3.5m to 3.7m 05/03/22 at 11:00. Flooding is not expected at other tidal gauge locations. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 14:00 on 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
We expect to see lower water levels for the Friday evening high tide. The Saturday morning high tide is now below the flood alert criteria.
No property flooding is expected and the forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides.
After this tide‚ the weather is more settled and no further impacts are expected but we will continue to monitor levels closely.
There may still be some areas where tidal flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.

items.description: River Trent from Cromwell Weir to Gainsborough
items.message: River levels are forecast to rise at the Torksey river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels. Flooding is possible on high tides at 23:00 on 04/03/22 and 11:00 on 05/03/22 at Torksey. Areas most at risk are Church Laneham to Rampton Road. We expect river levels to peak on the high tide at 23:30 on 05/03/22 at Torksey. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are patrolling watercourses in the area. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 20:00 on 04/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Sandhurst and Maisemore
items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Gloucester river gauge as a result of high spring tides coinciding with high river levels.  Flooding is possible on high tides at Gloucester over the next few days.  We expect flooding to affect Coal Wharf and Riverside, Maisemore, low lying areas on Base Lane, Sandhurst. Sandhurst Lane will be just passable. The A417 at Maisemore may be closed due to flooding. Predicted Peaks:- Sandhurst 3.6m to 3.8m 04/03/22 at 23:30 and 3.6m to 3.9m on 05/03/22 at 11:15, Gloucester 3.5m to 3.7m 04/03/22 at 22:45 and 3.5m to 3.7m 05/03/22 at 11:00.   
We expect river levels to remain high over the next 3 days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 14:00 on 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Cosford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding is imminent.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River from Crackley Bank to Bridgnorth. Other locations that may be affected include Ryton and Burcote.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday, 06/03/22. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated  by 9am on 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Trowlock Island tomorrow morning the 5th March at 5:00 am and is forecast to reach approximately 5.00-5.15 metres. The river is expected to overtop banks and flood low lying land. The following high tide is expected at 5:15 pm tomorrow and is forecast to reach approximately 5.00-5.15 metres. The river is expected to overtop banks and flood low lying land.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. The Thames Barrier is not currently forecast to close for the high tides tomorrow morning and evening. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rhee in Central Bedfordshire, Hertfordshire and Cambridgeshire
items.message: River levels are falling at the Wimpole river gauge, but levels remain high downstream following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Friday 04/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect River Rhee from Guilden Morden to Haslingfield. Further rainfall is forecast today, Friday 04/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high throughout today, Friday 04/03/22. River levels may rise again in response to further rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated this afternoon, 04/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message: River levels are high but steady at the Sutton Gault river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Friday 04/03/2022. We expect flooding to affect the Hundred Foot Washes, also known as the Ouse Washes. Further rainfall is forecast tonight, Friday 04/03/22, and tomorrow, Saturday 05/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday, 04/03/22. This information is correct as of 15:40 on Friday 04 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 18 centimetres of water on the road. There are currently no issues on the Welney or Earith causeways. Due to uneven surface of the road, water may be deeper in places. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow morning, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Sutton Gault river gauge following recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Friday 04/03/22. We expect flooding to affect The Causeway at Sutton Gault. Further rainfall is forecast tonight, Friday 04/03/22, and tomorrow, Saturday 05/03/22. We expect river levels to remain high throughout Friday, 04/03/2022. This information is correct as of 15:40 on Friday 04 March. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 18 centimetres of water on the road. Due to uneven surface of the road, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways, who will decide whether to close the road. This alert applies to SUTTON GAULT CAUSEWAY ONLY. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 08:00 tomorrow morning, 05/03/2022, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels on the Chertsey Bourne are continuing to fall slowly, but remain high and out of banks in some locations in Chertsey. Flooding of some low lying land and roads in Chertsey is therefore expected to continue this evening 04/03/22 and overnight. 
We expect river levels to remain high on the Chertsey Bourne overnight and tomorrow 05/03/22. River levels could rise again in response to further rainfall forecast tomorrow. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Clyst has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

River levels have continued to fall throughout today 03/03/22 on the Hoe Stream and the river is now back within its banks. There may still be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river, especially in the Woking area. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall overnight and tomorrow. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding is not currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are continuing to fall slowly, but remain high and out of banks in some locations on the Lower River Loddon. Flooding of low lying land and roads is therefore expected to continue this evening 04/03/22 and overnight, especially in and around Sindlesham Mill, Winnersh Triangle and Whistley Green.   
We expect river levels to remain high on the Lower River Loddon tomorrow 05/03/22. River levels could rise again in response to further rainfall forecast tomorrow.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Blackwater and The Cove Brook
items.message:
River levels have continued to fall throughout today 03/03/22 on the River Blackwater and Cove Brook and the river is now back within its banks. There may still be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river, especially in the Swallowfield area. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall overnight and tomorrow. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding is not currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

items.description: Windle Brook and Hale, Mill and Addlestone Bournes

floodArea.riverOrSea: Windle Brook, Hale Bourne, Mill Bourne, Addlestone Bourne

items.message:
River levels on the Addlestone Bourne remain high but are falling slowly and the river is flowing within its banks. There may be standing water in the floodplain in some low lying areas adjacent to the river. River levels could rise again in response to forecast rainfall today 04/03/22 and tomorrow. We will continue to monitor the weather forecast and reissue this alert if necessary, but further flooding isn’t currently expected.
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river level information.

items.description: River Thames from Hampton and Thames Ditton to Teddington

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are forecast to rise on the River Thames as a result of high tides. The next high tide is expected at Kingston tomorrow morning the 5th March at 5:00 am and is forecast to reach approximately 5-5.15 metres. The river could overtop banks and flood low lying land, roads and footpaths in some locations. The following high tide is expected at 5:15 pm tomorrow and is forecast to reach approximately 5-5.15 metres. The river could overtop banks and flood low lying land, roads and footpaths in some locations.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. The Thames Barrier is not currently forecast to close for the high tides tomorrow morning and evening. 
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 05/03/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message: The high tide at Richmond has now passed, and fluvial levels on the River Crane have now fallen below levels of concern.  No further flooding to gardens and low lying land is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.
